author: @infobae
title: El papa Francisco dijo que la guerra en Ucrania es un "acontecimiento vergonzoso para toda la humanidad" - Infobae
text:
El papa Francisco describi√≥ la guerra en Ucrania como un ‚Äúacontecimiento doloroso y vergonzoso para toda la humanidad‚Äù El papa Francisco , actualmente hospitalizado en el Policl√≠nico Gemelli de Roma debido a una neumon√≠a bilateral, emiti√≥ un mensaje de gran alcance este domingo, en el que calific√≥ la guerra en Ucrania como un ‚Äúacontecimiento doloroso y vergonzoso para toda la humanidad‚Äù .
Este mensaje, originalmente previsto para el rezo del √°ngelus, fue difundido por el Vaticano en un contexto en el que el pont√≠fice no pudo celebrarlo debido a su necesidad de descanso y tratamiento m√©dico.
El papa record√≥ que el lunes se cumplir√° el tercer aniversario del inicio de la invasi√≥n rusa a Ucrania, un conflicto que sigue causando dolor en la regi√≥n y que, seg√∫n Francisco, afecta de manera profunda a la humanidad.
‚Äú Ma√±ana se cumple el tercer aniversario de la guerra a gran escala contra Ucrania: ¬°un acontecimiento doloroso y vergonzoso para toda la humanidad!‚Äù , expres√≥ el pont√≠fice. En su mensaje, el papa reiter√≥ su cercan√≠a con el pueblo ucraniano, que ha sufrido durante m√°s de dos a√±os los devastadores efectos del conflicto.
A pesar de su condici√≥n m√©dica, Francisco no dej√≥ de manifestar su solidaridad con otros pueblos afectados por la violencia. En su mensaje, pidi√≥ oraciones por las v√≠ctimas de todos los conflictos armados y record√≥ a los pa√≠ses que siguen enfrentando graves crisis b√©licas. ‚ÄúLos invito a recordar a las v√≠ctimas de todos los conflictos armados y a rezar por el don de la paz en Palestina, en Israel y en todo Oriente Medio, en Myanmar, en Kivu y en Sud√°n‚Äù , a√±adi√≥.
El papa Francisco estrecha la mano del presidente ucraniano Volod√≠mir Zelenski, en el Vaticano, el 13 de mayo de 2023 (Vatican Media/REUTERS/Archivo) El mensaje del papa, difundido en formato escrito, se ofreci√≥ en lugar de la tradicional oraci√≥n del √°ngelus, como ocurri√≥ el domingo pasado, para que el pont√≠fice pudiera descansar debido a su estado de salud. Esta decisi√≥n fue tomada para garantizar su recuperaci√≥n y cumplir con los tratamientos necesarios mientras permanece en el hospital.
En su comunicado, el papa Francisco tambi√©n inform√≥ sobre su estado de salud, asegurando que ‚Äúcontin√∫a con confianza‚Äù su tratamiento en el hospital , destacando la importancia del descanso como parte de su proceso de recuperaci√≥n. ‚ÄúEl descanso tambi√©n forma parte de la terapia‚Äù , subray√≥ el pont√≠fice.
Agradecido por el apoyo recibido, Francisco expres√≥ su profunda gratitud hacia los m√©dicos y el personal sanitario del hospital Gemelli. ‚ÄúAgradezco de coraz√≥n a los m√©dicos y al personal sanitario de este hospital por la atenci√≥n que me est√°n demostrando y por la dedicaci√≥n con la que realizan su servicio entre las personas enfermas‚Äù, afirm√≥.
El papa, quien fue ingresado en el hospital el 14 de febrero tras sufrir una neumon√≠a bilateral, pas√≥ una noche tranquila y descans√≥, tras haber enfrentado una crisis respiratoria este s√°bado, lo que requiri√≥ la administraci√≥n de ox√≠geno y transfusiones de sangre debido a una anemia. Sin embargo, su estado sigue siendo estable , seg√∫n informaron las autoridades vaticanas.
El papa Francisco se encuentra hospitalizado en la cl√≠nica Gemelli, en Roma (Vatican News) En el mensaje, el pont√≠fice tambi√©n destac√≥ el impacto que han tenido en √©l los numerosos mensajes de apoyo y oraciones que ha recibido desde todo el mundo, especialmente las cartas y dibujos de ni√±os. ‚Äú En estos d√≠as me han llegado muchos mensajes de afecto y me han impresionado especialmente las cartas y dibujos de los ni√±os . ¬°Gracias por esta cercan√≠a y por las oraciones de confortaci√≥n que he recibido de todo el mundo!‚Äù, expres√≥.
Por su parte, el cardenal vicario de Roma, Baldo Reina , celebrar√° esta tarde en la bas√≠lica de San Juan de Letr√°n una misa especial en la que se pedir√° por la salud del papa Francisco. En la misa, se orar√° para que el Se√±or lo sostenga ‚Äúcon su gracia‚Äù y le brinde la fuerza necesaria para superar esta prueba.
(Con informaci√≥n de EFE)

author: Paola P√©rez
title: üå≤ Explore the Pine Barrens | Outdoorsy Newsletter
text:
Welcome to the dog days of summer.
These so-called Dog Days mark the climatologically hottest period of the season, which lasts through Aug. 21 . That‚Äôs right ‚Äî there‚Äôs more sweatiness on the way. But no worries, we‚Äôve got guides to feel fresh and stay safe in the heat so we can still have fun outdoors all season long.
Advertisement To cool off and unwind, Jason takes us to the only lake in Pennsylvania where you can escape to live the tranquil houseboat life .
But first, we‚Äôre exploring the Pine Barrens, a dreamscape of recreation and a beacon of preservation in our region .
‚òÄÔ∏è Your weekend weather outlook: Sunny days ahead with a slight reprieve from the oppressive heat. Stay hydrated and apply sunscreen.
‚Äî Paola P√©rez ( outdoorsy@inquirer.com )
If someone forwarded you this email, sign up for free here .
New Jersey‚Äôs own Middle Earth Enter the Pine Barrens, a vast open space spread across South Jersey with so much to soak up.
The Pine Barrens extend as far north as Plumsted, and as far south as mid- Cape May County. The Garden State Parkway forms its eastern border, and parts of four municipalities form its western front, including parts of Mount Holly and Medford.
It‚Äôs a forestland, safe from suburban sprawl, with access to hiking trails, kayaking, canoeing, fishing, and lookout spots with stellar views.
And good food. We can‚Äôt forget the food. (Fun fact: Anthony Bourdain visited a diner here in 2015!)
Before you go, there‚Äôs a few things you should know:
üì± Cell reception may be spotty , so grab a physical map in case your coverage stops you in your tracks
üêõ Bugs are a problem , especially ticks, biting flies, and mosquitoes, so don‚Äôt forget to pack anti-bug sprays and wear appropriate clothing.
üöó Be careful driving , because some dirt roads may be not be as reasonably maintained as paved ones. Also, avoid going through puddles if you are unsure about their depth.
üè† Remember the ‚ÄúPineys,‚Äù the people who live there. This landscape, while it is more or less nature‚Äôs theme park, is home to proud locals.
Ready? Let us show you exactly where to start your journey through the Pine Barrens .
Tranquility on the lake üé§ Now we‚Äôre passing the microphone to Jason Nark. You‚Äôll always find his work here.
In the Deep South, in places far from the surf, ‚Äúlake life‚Äù is a big deal, and boating is more than a hobby.
There‚Äôs a slew of country songs about the lifestyle, too, tunes about specific rivers where it gets hotter than a ‚Äúhoochie coochie,‚Äù as described in Alan Jackson‚Äôs ‚ÄúChattahoochee,‚Äù and others about particular boats like the pontoon. There‚Äôs even a Merle Haggard song about houseboats, which are like pontoons with small houses on them, an aquatic RV more or less.
Jeremy Hetrick, a South Carolina native, knows all about lake life, but mostly because he‚Äôs the administrative assistant at Seven Points Marina on Raystown Lake, the largest lake entirely within Pennsylvania (the state has 77 miles of Lake Erie shoreline). Raystown, created by a hydroelectric dam process in 1973, is a whopping 8,300 acres. The lake is managed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, and, unlike other large bodies of water in Pennsylvania, like Lake Wallenpaupack and Harveys and Conneaut Lakes, Raystown has undergone almost no development.
There‚Äôs not a single house on its 118 miles of shoreline, but there‚Äôs a ton of houseboats, like the eight-person model Hetrick is about to board on the marina‚Äôs long network of docks. ‚Äî Jason Nark
Go deeper into the lake‚Äôs houseboat culture ‚Äî and what you can expect if you rent one .
News worth knowing Heads up, Mile Trail frequenters, part of the popular paved trail is closed while officials investigate a possible chemical contamination at a site near Bartram‚Äôs Garden .
The Philadelphia Youth Regatta, the largest one-day sprint regatta in the world, takes over the Schuylkill River this weekend with more than 700 races scheduled .
Yogis who baked Yoga on the Banks into their routines over the last decade must now abruptly say goodbye to the beloved outdoor workout class on Sunday .
A microbiologist explains how to avoid getting sick when gangs of germs are lurking in the woods, in the soil, in the water, and in your food, ready to rain on your summer parade .
Catch a flick al fresco (for free!) with the help of our guide to watch outdoor movies in Philly all summer long .
10 seconds of calm üé§ Jason says: This is in Hammersley Wild Area in Western Pennsylvania.
So soothing.
Your outdoorsy experience Mike Schultheis of Royersford, Montgomery County , shared this delightful image and story with us:
My wife and I used to disappear for our annual fall getaway, staying at Cherry Mills Lodge in Dushore in October. Alas it was bought, changed and now closed but was a great, well run laid back B&B where the Little Loyalsock Creek splashing below our window sent you off to a most peaceful sleep. The trip also included well deserved respite at Eagles Mere Inn‚Äôs, A.C. Little‚Äôs Drinkery for great food and camaraderie after a day of traipsing around Ricketts Glen, feeding Kahlo and Valerie at Artisan Alpacas, drinking in the sunset from High Knob and finding fossils in Loyalsock Creek. Then in 2019, there was Cold Run ‚Äúroad‚Äù to the canyon vista. Barely a car wide with a shear cliff on one side that I will forever be grateful to our Subaru ‚ÄúForrest‚Äù for getting us up top and for no car coming the other way. Even though the leaves were past peak this view made it so worthwhile. Our world then breathed relief and put an end to any worries. I think we sat and stared for almost an hour of calm. Also think we should go back. What‚Äôs a little terror if the end justifies the journey? Hmmm‚Ä¶
My thoughts exactly.
üìÆ Give us a review of your outdoors experience for a chance to be featured in this newsletter by emailing me back .
üëãüèΩ I hope you get a moment to bask in the glory of nature very soon. See you again next week.
By submitting your written, visual, and/or audio contributions, you agree to The Inquirer‚Äôs Terms of Use , including the grant of rights in Section 10.

author: Canadian Press
title: Friends and family mourn the loss of Canadians killed by Hamas in Israel
text: Friends, family and government officials have confirmed that at least seven Canadians were killed when Hamas militants conducted a series of attacks in Israel on Oct. 7. Global Affairs Canada has said an eighthperson who was not a citizen but had deep ties to Canada also died in the ensuing conflict. Another Canadian, who has not been identified, died in Lebanon during the hostilities. The Hamas attacks killed an estimated 1,200 people and militants took another 240 hostage, 105 of whom were released during a temporary pause in the violence at the end of last month. As Israel continues its retaliation on Hamas in the Gaza Strip, authorities there say more than 20,000 Palestinians have now been killed. Here's what we know about the Hamas victimswith ties to Canada: Judih Weinstein Haggai Judih Weinstein Haggai, 70, was out on an early-morning walk when Hamas started its attack, her family says. She told members of her Nir Oz kibbutz that a militant on a motorcycle shot her husband and she was less severely wounded. The community was unable to dispatch an ambulance before militants arrived there. Last week, the kibbutz confirmed Gadi Haggai, Judih's husband, died on Oct. 7, and on Thursday they confirmed Weinstein Haggai also died that day, and her body is being held in Gaza. Weinstein Haggai was born in New York state but arrived in Toronto at the age of three, and moved to Israel 20 years later to live with her husband. She held Canadian, Israeli and American citizenships. Weinstein Haggai was an artist and a volunteer who the kibbutz said "pursued many initiatives to advance peace in the region." Her brother Larry Weinstein said the family is distressed by Israel's offensive in Gaza and the rise of hateful speech in Canada toward both Jews and Muslims. "We're inspired by my sister, who believed in peace and believed in harmony," he said. "There can't be any kind of resolution when people are at each other's throats." Vivian Silver Vivian Silver, 74, was in her home on Kibbutz Be'eri near the Gaza border and talking on the phone with her son Yonatan Zeigen when they learned of the incursion by Hamas into Israel. "We couldn‚Äôt grasp the incapability of the Israeli army to defend the civilians ‚Ä¶ we started to say goodbye because we realized this is probably our last words to each other," Zeigen later told a news conference organized by the Jerusalem Press Club. He said they shifted their conversations to text messages so his mother could stay silent, and someone broke into her home. They said they loved one another before the messages stopped coming. Zeigen said he had received information that she was taken hostage, and her phone had been geolocated in Gaza. On Monday, his brother Chen Zeigen confirmed their mother's death. He said Israeli authorities told him the remains found earlier in the kibbutz had been identified as Silver. He said his mother was born in Winnipeg and moved to Israel in 1974. She dedicated her life to peacebuilding and fostering understanding between Israelis and Palestinians, he added. She also volunteered to help children in Gaza access medical care in Israel. Tiferet Lapidot Tiferet Lapidot, 22, was a few days shy of her 23rd birthday and attending a music festival when the Hamas attack began. Her cousin Oran Zlotnik remembered Lapidot as a charismatic and compassionate person who had travelled the world, taught in Africa and spent time in Australia before she returned to Israel in the fall. Her uncle Harel Lapidot said she called her mother the morning of the attack to say she was hiding in a bush and to ask whether she should flee. Her cellphone was later tracked to the Gaza Strip, leading family to believe she was being held hostage. They then mounted a campaign to secure her freedom. Zlotnik said that when the cellphone of one of Lapidot's friends, confirmed deceased, was also traced to Gaza, the family realized it was possible she wasn't a hostage. Harel Lapidot said his niece's body was later identified and the family held a funeral. "We know for a fact they were hunted," he said. "They ran away and they were hunted and killed." Tiferet Lapidot was an Israeli citizen but her family was from Canada, including her father, Ohad, who was born in Saskatchewan. Harel Lapidot thanked the Jewish community in Canada and MPs who had reached out to help and offer support. The family had a meeting with Foreign Affairs Minister M√©lanie Joly while she was in Israel. Netta Epstein Israeli-Canadian Netta Epstein, 21, died when his home, Kibbutz Kfar Aza, came under attack. His mother, Ayelet Shachar-Epstein, said he loved life. She learned the circumstances of his death from text messages he sent her in the moments before he was killed, and from his fianc√©e, Irene Shavit, who survived. Netta Epstein was inside a safe room with Shavit, and he jumped on a grenade thrown in by the attackers. Shachar-Epstein, who also lost her mother-in-law and two brothers-in-law in the attacks, described it as a terrorist invasion. She said her son, who had worked with special needs youth, had returned home two months earlier after completing military service. He was born in Montreal and was a Canadian citizen. Shachar-Epstein said many members of the family still live in that city. Shir Georgy Israeli Canadian Shir Georgy, 22, was killed by Hamas militants who ambushed the music festival near Kibbutz Re'im. Georgy's aunt Michal Bouganim confirmed the death. "We are currently a mess, heartbroken," Bouganim said in a Facebook message. Bouganim shared a 22-second clip on her social media in which a terrified Georgy was seen sitting on a floor, with her back against a wall and surrounded by other festival attendees ‚Äî some of them injured. Georgy's funeral was held in Israel. Adi Vital-Kaploun Adi Vital-Kaploun, 33, was killed by Hamas militants in her kibbutz near the Israeli border with the Gaza Strip, said the Jewish Federation of Ottawa. The group's CEO made a statement on behalf of Vital-Kaploun's family, saying the dual citizen has a large extended family in the Ottawa area. The family said she died a hero, after convincing her killers to spare her two young children and warning her father and husband to stay hidden during the attack. "Adi was a beautiful woman that brought love and lightness to the people around her, but also she was very focused and determined to make a beautiful life for her family," her cousin-in-law Aaron Smith said in an interview. The family said she was an amazing mother and wife, always bringing love and laughter to their household. She was also a talented dancer, saxophonist and basketball player. After completing her master's degree in engineering, Vital-Kaploun excelled in her cybersecurity career, they said. "We are mourning trying to process this unconscionable act of terrorism in her kibbutz and across the country," said the family, adding that they wish her memory to be "a blessing." Ben Mizrachi Canadian Ben Mizrachi was one of at least 260 people gunned down by Hamas militants at the music festival in southern Israel. Mizrachi, 22, from Vancouver, was described as "larger than life with a big personality" in a statement by his former high school in B.C. Ezra Shanken, CEO of the Jewish Federation of Greater Vancouver, said Mizrachi was about to start university in Israel after serving with the country's national defence force. Hilit Nurick, a home economics teacher at King David High School in Vancouver, remembered Mizrachi as a "kind, wonderful, and community-minded" young man who had a positive influence on everyone around him. Nurick said she and Mizrachi once put a large event together for more than 100 people at school. "He was in charge of making Moroccan-style spicy fish stew. He brought his mother's recipe and shared it with everyone and taught us how to make it," said Nurick. "He was incredible, just an incredible human being." Alexandre Look Alexandre Look, who had recently celebrated his 33rd birthday, was among those killed while attending the musical festival. Look, who lived in Montreal with his family before moving to Mexico, died a hero, his dad said in a Facebook post. "Like a true warrior he left as a hero wanting to protect the people he was with," Alain Haim Look said. Friend Lior Horovitz described him as a "once-in-a-lifetime person" who became like family during their five-year friendship. In a phone interview from a town outside Tel Aviv, she said she and her boyfriend met Alexandre Look in Mexico. They became fast friends and would organize their vacations to meet up, either in Mexico or Israel. He was a proud Jewish Canadian and a generous person who would do anything for his friends, she said. "He's a person who loves people," she said. "He's the guy that's always going to help others, especially if they are Jewish." This report by The Canadian Press was first published Dec. 28, 2023. The Canadian Press

persons.name: judih weinstein haggai judih weinstein haggai

author: JJ Stankevitz
title: For Colts' defensive line, record-setting sacks are key to wins ‚Äì but not the group's focus
text: A year ago, the Colts' defensive line was chasing the wrong thing. The Colts had 43 sacks with two games left, four shy of setting an Indianapolis-era franchise record. The defensive line was chasing the record, not the process that would get them the record. And there were too many selfish rushes and not enough of a collective pass rush. Over the final two games of 2022, the Colts had one sack. In 2023, defensive line coach Nate Ollie doubled down on his core message, one that's resonated with a defensive line that got its record-setting 47th sack last week against the Atlanta Falcons. "We really talk about chasing God and putting God first," Ollie said. "And if we do that and chase him, everything else will fall into place." Through a commitment to unselfish, four-as-one pass rushes, the Colts' defense has one of the most impactful fronts in the NFL. Three players have eight or more sacks (Kwity Paye, Dayo Odeyingbo, Samson Ebukam), and 14 different players have at least a half-sack. The Colts are 7-0 when generating four or more sacks this season, and the impact of the sacks in those games has been significant. Of the 33 possessions in those seven wins on which the Colts have had at least one sack, those drives have ended like this: |Drive end event||Count| |Punt||17| |Field goal makes/attempts||5/7| |Turnovers||5| |End of half/game||2| |Turnover on downs||1| |Touchdowns||1| In those seven games with four or more sacks, the Colts allowed their opponents to score on 27.1 percent of their possessions, underscoring the cumulative impact of getting opposing quarterbacks to the ground so frequently. "You can kind of feel when you're winning early, you got the O-line on their heels, they're more susceptible to more moves because they're kind of playing on there heels, they're focused on what they got beat on earlier," Odeyingbo said. "So it kind of sets up other moves." Another aspect to why the Colts' defense has made such a major impact through sacks is the depth with which they're able to play. Ollie is constantly rotating his "alpha" and "bravo" groups, subbing four guys on and off like an NHL line change. And through the play of linemen like Tyquan Lewis and Jake Martin, the Colts haven't had a significant dropoff when Ebukam, Paye, DeForest Buckner, etc. come off the field. "We take pride in not having a weak link," Ollie said. "And that's when you can roll as a group, you can go out there and you could go four guys on and four guys off like hockey subs. If you can do that, any front you're on, you got a good group of guys." While these sacks have come in bunches, they haven't come in every game this season. The Colts are 1-7 when getting three or fewer sacks, with that lone win coming in a one-sack Week 5 over the Tennessee Titans. Opponents are scoring on 49 percent of their possessions in those eight games. The difference, defensive coordinator Gus Bradley said, is the Colts generally haven't been able to contain opposition running backs in those seven defeats. "Looking back at the last couple games where we didn't play well, the backs have come alive against us," Bradley said. "Cincinnati, it was the screen game. This past game, (Bijan) Robinson did a good job ‚Äì both backs did a good job against us. We gave up some explosive plays whether it was them catching balls on passes, screen game, or on some of the runs. I think that's a common thread right now that we have to take care of ‚Äì is slowing down these running back type plays that are getting yards against us." In those seven games with four-plus sacks, the Colts are holding opposing running backs to 4.7 yards per touch; in their other eight games running backs are averaging 5.8 yards per touch (the NFL average is 5.2 yards per touch allowed to running backs). "That's the only way to eventually rush the passer is stopping the run first, getting them behind the chains, forcing them to call riskier plays and try to call longer-developing plays down the field," Odeyingbo said. "So that kind of opens up opportunities for sacks." Ollie doesn't focus on sacks with his defensive line, though. The thing he's more interested in is the defensive line's effort board, which tracks "special efforts" ‚Äì like a defensive lineman running downfield to make a tackle. The Colts have more of those high-effort plays than they do sacks. But the sacks also won't come without the commitment to those high-effort plays. And they'll need both to win their way into the playoffs over the season's final two weeks. "That's more a testament of the group than the sacks, just the effort that those guys play with each and every day," Ollie said. "In order to do that, you gotta be able to sub four guys in, four guys off and not missing a beat."

author: @eleconomista
title: Putin reconoce que las \"diferencias\" con Brasil impiden la entrada de Venezuela en los BRICS
text: [Geopol√≠tica](/internacionales) Lectura 2:00 min Putin reconoce que las "diferencias" con Brasil impiden la entrada de Venezuela en los BRICS Putin ha expresado que conf√≠a en que las relaciones entre Brasil y Venezuela retomen su tradicional normalidad. El presidente de [Rusia](https://www.eleconomista.com.mx/videos/ucrania-afirma-rusia-desplego-soldados-norcoreanos-region-kursk-20241024-731407.html), Vladimir Putin, ha reconocido este jueves que su postura con respecto a Venezuela difiere de la del Gobierno de Brasil y conf√≠a en una futura adhesi√≥n del pa√≠s en los BRICS. "La regla para admitir a cualquier candidato es que haya consenso", ha dicho en rueda de prensa. "Se necesita que est√©n de acuerdo todos los miembros de la organizaci√≥n. Sin eso es imposible dar ese paso", ha dicho Putin cuando se le ha preguntado por la ausencia de Venezuela en el grupo de doce pa√≠ses que han sido este jueves incluidos como Estados socio, como paso previo a su inclusi√≥n definitiva. "Nuestras posiciones no coinciden con las de [Brasil] la cuesti√≥n de Venezuela. Lo digo abiertamente", ha reconocido el presidente ruso, quien ha respaldo la victoria de su par venezolano, [Nicol√°s Maduro](https://www.eleconomista.com.mx/internacionales/apuntalado-brics-putin-quiere-afianzarse-frente-occidente-20241023-731309.html), en las √∫ltimas y pol√©micas elecciones. En ese sentido, Putin ha expresado que conf√≠a en que las relaciones entre Brasil y Venezuela retomen su tradicional normalidad. En la v√≠spera, los medios brasile√±os adelantaron que Venezuela y Nicaragua se quedaban fuera, a petici√≥n de Brasil, de una lista finalmente formada por doce pa√≠ses que pasar√≠an a ser catalogados como Estados socios de los BRICS, entre ellos Bolivia, Cuba, Nigeria, Bielorrusia, Indonesia, o Vietnam. Las relaciones entre Venezuela y Brasil no pasan por su mejor momento, despu√©s de que el presidente Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva, si bien sin ser tan expl√≠citos como otros l√≠deres de la regi√≥n, ha reprochado a [Maduro](https://www.eleconomista.com.mx/internacionales/brics-piden-guerra-y-mas-financiacion-entregan-detalles-20241023-731198.html) que no haya todav√≠a presentado pruebas de su triunfo en las elecciones.

author: Scot Lehigh
title: Opinion | Ed Markey on climate change: Don‚Äôt cede future to China
text:
As someone increasingly pessimistic about the world‚Äôs ability to mount the carbon dioxide-curbing effort necessary to stave off the worst impacts of global warming, I‚Äôm always heartened to talk to Senator Ed Markey, a relentlessly upbeat leader in the climate struggle.
But before we turn to Mr. Optimistic, let‚Äôs have a little gloom and doom. Long predicted, the dangerous effects of climate change have arrived in an unmistakable (and what would in a more rational nation be an undeniable) way. Much of the country now swelters under dangerous heat waves during summer. In mid-July, regions with upward of 135 million Americans were under heat alerts.
Around the world, previous high-temperature records have toppled like candlepins in a bowling tournament. Heat-related causes killed more than 47,000 Europeans in 2023, according to a new study. Deaths from heat hit 2,300 in this country in 2023, up 34 percent from the previous year.
Depressed? Well, here‚Äôs Markey with some good news as this country marks the second anniversary of the incentive-based climate law known as the Inflation Reduction Act.
Advertisement
‚ÄúThis year, there is going to be 36,000 new megawatts of solar [electricity] installed in the United States, and 8,000 new megawatts of wind installed in the United States,‚Äù Markey said during a phone conversation. (Nationally, solar power is projected to be 58 percent of the total new electrical capacity added this year, according to the US Energy Information Administration. ) Markey‚Äôs office estimates that when that new solar and wind power is fully available, it will meet the electricity needs of more than 9 million households.
The IRA has now leveraged some $370 billion in private-sector investments, which accounts for the creation of some 335,000 clean energy jobs, the senator said, citing Climate Power.
Indeed, renewable energy, and particularly solar, has taken strong enough root in red and purple states to begin to change the perspective of a GOP whose fossil fuel funding had long made it resistant to most things green. Last week, 18 House Republicans wrote to Speaker Mike Johnson opposing repeal of the energy tax credits in the IRA.
Advertisement
‚ÄúEnergy tax credits have spurred innovation, incentivized investment, and created good jobs in many parts of the country ‚Äî including many districts represented by members of our conference,‚Äù they declared.
But that is unlikely to deter Donald Trump‚Äôs aversion to renewable energy should he retake the White House.
On the campaign trail, Trump has vowed to target ‚Äúall new spending grants and giveaways under the Joe Biden mammoth socialist bills like the so-called Inflation Reduction Act,‚Äù adding that ‚Äúwe‚Äôre going to save all that money.‚Äù According to The Washington Post, during an April fund-raiser with oil-industry executives, Trump promised to end much of the Biden administration‚Äôs green-energy agenda, taking particular aim at wind-generated energy and electric vehicles, and promising to bolster the fossil fuel industry. He then asked the petroleum panjandrums to raise $1 billion for his comeback effort.
A man who considers climate change a hoax, Trump has adopted Sarah Palin‚Äôs energy slogan: Drill, baby, drill. He would again take the United States out of the Paris c limate agreement, which sets voluntary targets for reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, keyed to a country‚Äôs level of development, capabilities, and emissions history. The United States, the largest emitter over time, has a more stringent voluntary-reductions schedule than do China and India. That gives conservatives agita, but it‚Äôs better to have a voluntary agreement with differentiated national targets than no agreement at all ‚Äî at least for those who acknowledge the threat of human-caused global warming.
For his part, Markey offers a seize-the-future economic argument for the IRA‚Äôs tax credits, deductions, grants, and loans : With China trying to dominate the solar and wind energy, electric vehicle, and battery sectors, the IRA has given US producers a vital boost to help them compete.
Advertisement

author: Zone Divertissement - ICI.Radio-Canada.ca
title: Apr√®s la bord√©e de neige tant attendue, les skieurs manitobains renouent avec leur sport | Radio-Canada
text: Apr√®s la bord√©e de neige tant attendue, les skieurs manitobains renouent avec leur sport Apr√®s une longue attente, la saison de ski de fond est officiellement lanc√©e dans le sud du Manitoba. Photo : Radio-Canada Les fondeurs manitobains √©taient tout sourire sur les pistes, vendredi, √† l‚Äôouverture des sentiers, apr√®s avoir longtemps attendu une bonne bord√©e de neige. Cela a notamment √©t√© le cas au parc Assiniboine et au parc Windsor, dans le quartier de Saint-Vital, √† Winnipeg, o√π les sentiers ont pu accueillir leurs premiers amateurs de ski de fond, apr√®s la bord√©e de neige tomb√©e entre mercredi soir et jeudi soir. Selon Environnement Canada, une vingtaine de centim√®tres ont √©t√© enregistr√©s. Le temps doux et l‚Äôabsence de grandes quantit√©s de neige ont marqu√© l‚Äôhiver dans le sud du Manitoba jusque-l√†. D‚Äôhabitude, on peut commencer √† skier vers la fin novembre ou d√©but d√©cembre. √á‚Äôa √©t√© une longue attente, raconte Calvin Wiebe. J‚Äô√©tais excit√© en voyant la neige hier [jeudi]. L‚Äôan dernier, j‚Äôai ski√© 30 fois, mais cette ann√©e on n‚Äôavait pas eu la chance de skier. √Ä lire aussi : C‚Äôest l‚Äôouverture la plus tardive pour ce centre de ski fr√©quent√© par les fondeurs depuis les ann√©es 70. Nous ne sommes pas malheureux de ce fait. On a de la belle neige et on peut accueillir des skieurs, affirme le gestionnaire du Centre Nordic au parc Windsor, Laurie Penton. Quand je regardais les pr√©visions, on annon√ßait de la pluie et, finalement, √ß‚Äôa √©t√© de la neige. Ce fut une belle surprise. M. Penton affirme que les skieurs avaient h√¢te de chausser leurs skis. Il affirme avoir √©t√© surpris d'avoir accueilli un flux constant de clients, alors qu‚Äôil croyait que la temp√©rature basse allait ralentir leurs ardeurs. Le thermom√®tre affichait -20 ¬∞C, vendredi apr√®s-midi, √† Winnipeg, avec un refroidissement √©olien de -31. Malgr√© la premi√®re chute de neige, Laurie Penton esp√®re qu'il y aura d‚Äôautres pr√©cipitations de neige alors que, dans certains secteurs, il n‚Äôy en a pas assez pour √©tablir correctement un sentier. Il estime que 70 % du r√©seau skiable est ouvert au parc Windsor. Il se r√©jouit toutefois que des pr√©cipitations de neige soient pr√©vues au cours de la semaine. Derek Page, un des skieurs, a appr√©ci√© l‚Äô√©tat des pistes durant sa sortie vendredi. Je reviens d‚Äôun petit 5 kilom√®tres, affirme-t-il. J‚Äôai pr√©par√© la cire ce matin, il fait beau, m√™me si c‚Äôest un peu froid. Les pistes √©taient tr√®s belles. Avec les informations de Richard Sabeh

author: Mesa de noticias de El Mostrador
title: Con apagones y ca√Édas de arboles sistema frontal llega a Santiago: suspenden clases en regiones
text:
Pasada la medianoche, 777,599 hogares permanec√Éan sin suministro el√É¬©ctrico en las regiones Metropolitana, Valpara√Éso, O‚ÄôHiggins, Maule, √É‚Äòuble, Biob√Éo, La Araucan√Éa, Los R√Éos y Los Lagos, seg√É¬∫n la SEC.
Resumen S√Éntesis generada con OpenAI Un fuerte sistema frontal afect√É¬≥ al centro-sur de Chile, causando estragos en Santiago con vientos que rompieron ventanales, volaron techumbres y derribaron √É¬°rboles, afectando el suministro el√É¬©ctrico en varias comunas. En Lo Barnechea, un √É¬°rbol cay√É¬≥ sobre un local comercial, dejando lesionados. La suspensi√É¬≥n de clases se autoriz√É¬≥ en varias regiones, excluyendo la Metropolitana. Hasta la medianoche, 777,599 hogares segu√Éan sin electricidad en diversas regiones. La situaci√É¬≥n es cr√Ética con da√É¬±os significativos y cortes de luz. Desarrollado por El Mostrador El sistema frontal que afecta al centro-sur del pa√És lleg√É¬≥ con fuerza a Santiago, dejando m√É¬∫ltiples da√É¬±os en varias comunas de la Regi√É¬≥n Metropolitana. Los fuertes vientos causaron estragos en la zona oriente, con reportes de ventanales rotos, techumbres voladas y √É¬°rboles ca√Édos. Usuarios de redes sociales informaron sobre las afectaciones, incluyendo la ca√Éda de maceteros desde terrazas que impactaron en parabrisas y techos de veh√Éculos.
Uno de los incidentes registrados hasta ahora ocurri√É¬≥ en Lo Barnechea, en la intersecci√É¬≥n de Avenida Ra√É¬∫l Labb√É¬© con Avenida Las Condes. Un √É¬°rbol cay√É¬≥ sobre un local comercial, dejando al menos dos personas lesionadas y una atrapada. Bomberos trabajaron en el lugar para socorrer a los afectados.
Un usuario de redes sociales describi√É¬≥ la situaci√É¬≥n en Lo Barnechea como √¢‚Ç¨≈ìuna tragedia√¢‚Ç¨ÔøΩ, mencionando que muchas casas y edificios sufrieron da√É¬±os en sus techos.
Otro usuario report√É¬≥ la ca√Éda de un √É¬°rbol en Providencia, en calle Suecia con Bustos, que rompi√É¬≥ la reja de una casa y cay√É¬≥ al otro lado de la calle.
En diversas comunas de la zona oriente, como Pe√É¬±alol√É¬©n, La Reina, Las Condes y Lo Barnechea, se registraron cortes de suministro el√É¬©ctrico debido a la ca√Éda de ramas y √É¬°rboles, lo que tambi√É¬©n bloque√É¬≥ rutas y afect√É¬≥ tendidos el√É¬©ctricos, provocando la explosi√É¬≥n de algunos transformadores.
El viento tambi√É¬©n gener√É¬≥ problemas en la comuna de Las Condes. √¢‚Ç¨≈ìEn el piso 15 de un edificio se nos quebr√É¬≥ un ventanal por la fuerza del viento√¢‚Ç¨≈ì, report√É¬≥ un auditor de la radio Biob√Éo .
ƒü≈∏‚Ä†Àú√Ø¬∏ÔøΩ Llegando a rotonda Tomas Moro
√Ç¬°En la plaza Manuel Claro Vial, el viento arranc√É¬≥ √É¬°rboles y tendido el√É¬©ctrico se encuentra en el piso!
Calle intransitable @biobio @Muni_LasCondes #temporal #lascondes pic.twitter.com/EqiTi9pHyq
√¢‚Ç¨‚Äù Felipe Stipo (@FStipo) August 2, 2024
En otras √É¬°reas como Maip√É¬∫ y Cerrillos, los reportes indicaron condiciones m√É¬°s tranquilas sin fuertes vientos ni lluvias. Sin embargo, en comunas como √É‚Äòu√É¬±oa, el viento caus√É¬≥ cortes de luz y ca√Éda de √É¬°rboles, generando preocupaci√É¬≥n entre los residentes.
Impresionante
Im√É¬°genes del colapso y ca√Éda de antena de telefon√Éa qu√É¬© se encuentra al Interior de la Octava Compa√É¬±√Éa de Bomberos de √É‚Äòu√É¬±oa ubicada en la comuna de Pe√É¬±alol√É¬©n, r√É¬°fagas de viento superaron los 60 Km/h @biobio @chile_accidente @Louisvasquez23 @Pabl0Manzanares pic.twitter.com/9RUHiE73Dz
√¢‚Ç¨‚Äù IEC-180 CONTROL STGO (@fdo2000) August 2, 2024
Pasada la medianoche, 777,599 hogares permanec√Éan sin suministro el√É¬©ctrico en las regiones Metropolitana, Valpara√Éso, O‚ÄôHiggins, Maule, √É‚Äòuble, Biob√Éo, La Araucan√Éa, Los R√Éos y Los Lagos, seg√É¬∫n la SEC.
Y yo que me quer√Éa acostar temprano. #viento pic.twitter.com/KAywuBrVZS
√¢‚Ç¨‚Äù Diego Apablaza (@dagoapa) August 2, 2024
Suspensi√É¬≥n de clases en regiones Debido al intenso sistema frontal que afecta desde el jueves al centro y sur de Chile, el Ministerio de Educaci√É¬≥n autoriz√É¬≥ para este viernes, 2 de agosto, la suspensi√É¬≥n de clases en varios establecimientos educacionales a solicitud de los equipos sostenedores, situados entre las regiones de Coquimbo y Los Lagos, con excepci√É¬≥n de la Regi√É¬≥n Metropolitana √¢‚Ç¨‚Äùpor ahora√¢‚Ç¨‚Äù.
En tres regiones -Coquimbo, Biob√Éo y La Araucan√Éa- la suspensi√É¬≥n ser√É¬° completa para todas las comunas. En Coquimbo, la suspensi√É¬≥n incluye todos los jardines Junji, Integra y VTF, as√É como todos los establecimientos educacionales p√É¬∫blicos, particulares subvencionados y particulares pagados.
En la Regi√É¬≥n de Valpara√Éso habr√É¬° suspensi√É¬≥n preventiva en establecimientos municipales de 16 comunas y cierre parcial en algunas comunas espec√Éficas. En la Regi√É¬≥n Metropolitana no habr√É¬° suspensi√É¬≥n de clases.
En la Regi√É¬≥n de O‚ÄôHiggins se suspenden las clases en todas las escuelas de las comunas de Navidad, Paredones y Pichilemu, y en Rancagua, en establecimientos municipales. En el Maule, la suspensi√É¬≥n afectar√É¬° a las comunas de Pelluhue y Curepto, y a los jardines Junji e Integra en Chanco y Constituci√É¬≥n.
Viento y lluvia en San Fernando cortes de luz y agua #temporal #viento #sanfernando pic.twitter.com/wfPwPgXFBC
√¢‚Ç¨‚Äù √¢ÔøΩ‚Ä¢Nicolas Athuan (@NicolasAthuanAP) August 2, 2024
En √É‚Äòuble, la suspensi√É¬≥n se aplicar√É¬° a establecimientos municipales en 10 comunas, y en tres establecimientos educacionales espec√Éficos por da√É¬±os en infraestructura. En el Biob√Éo y La Araucan√Éa, la suspensi√É¬≥n ser√É¬° completa para todas las comunas y tipos de establecimientos.
En Los R√Éos, la suspensi√É¬≥n afectar√É¬° a 10 comunas y en Los Lagos a varias comunas y establecimientos espec√Éficos. Adem√É¬°s, cierran los establecimientos del SLEP Llanquihue y varios colegios particulares subvencionados en distintas comunas.

author: Mario D√≠az
title: Rusia avanza sin freno hacia Pokrovsk, nudo log√≠stico clave de Ucrania en el frente de Donestk
text:
Ucrania avanza en Kursk. Ucrania bombardea Crimea. Ucrania intenta irrupmpir en la regi√≥n de Bryansk. Y sin embargo, sin que nadie le preste demasiada atenci√≥n, Rusia sigue avanzando en Donestk, donde, probablemente, ha hecho los mayores progresos de los √∫ltimos meses. Analistas militares ucranianos creen en cualquier caso que el ritmo del avance enemigo pronto se ralentizar√°.
El Ministerio de Defensa de Rusia ha anunciado en su parte de guerra diario la toma de la localidad ucraniana de Mezhove como parte de su avance hacia el nudo log√≠stico de Pokrovsk. Un avance nimio pero fundamental, en tanto que esa localidad con poco m√°s de mil habitantes, antes del comienzo de la guerra, est√° a unos 24 kil√≥metros de Pokrovsk, un objetivo codiciado por las fuerzas rusas, ya que su toma afectar√≠a la log√≠stica del Ej√©rcito ucraniano en esta regi√≥n.
Seg√∫n Defensa, la agrupaci√≥n militar Tsentr enfrent√≥ en este sector las fuerzas de siete brigadas ucranianas de infanter√≠a, motorizadas, aerotransportadas y defensa territorial y repeli√≥ cinco contraataques ucranianos, ocasionando unas 640 bajas.
La v√≠spera, el Ej√©rcito ruso anunci√≥ la toma de la localidad de Zhelanne, en este mismo sector.
La intensidad de los asaltos rusos en la zona no ha decrecido desde el inicio de la operaci√≥n ucraniana en Kursk, dijo a EFE este jueves Iv√°n Si√©kach , portavoz de la 110¬™ Brigada Mecanizada del Ej√©rcito ucraniano. Las localidades de Zavitne, Komishivka y Novozhelanne tambi√©n han sido tomadas por los rusos en un intento de asegurar sus flancos a lo largo del eje de su avance hacia Pokrovsk.
Sin embargo es posible que los avances de Mosc√∫ se ralenticen pronto debido a la necesidad de evitar los contraataques ucranianos contra el flanco izquierdo y gracias al terreno m√°s elevado que ocupan las posiciones ucranianas m√°s cercanas a Pokrovsk, escribe el coronel en la reserva y analista militar Kostiant√≠n Mashov√©ts .
Voluntarios evacuan a la poblaci√≥n civil de Pokrovsk ante el avance de las tropas rusas. Reuters
En un an√°lisis para Resistencia Informativa , Mashov√©ts admite que quiz√° las fuerzas ucranianas, num√©ricamente inferiores, no sean capaces de detener la presi√≥n rusa durante mucho tiempo a lo largo de las posiciones m√°s favorables entre Selidove al sur y Yelisavetivka al norte. De hecho, las unidades de avanzada rusas ya han penetrado esta barrera potencial en Krasni Yar y Novogrodivka.
Debido al uso pr√°cticamente irrestricto de bombas a√©reas, Rusia puede destruir incluso las posiciones defensivas m√°s fuertes y "evaporar" a quienes las defienden, se√±ala Si√©kach. Aunque, las fuerzas rusas tendr√°n que reagruparse y bajar el ritmo ante la amenaza de un contraataque desde Selidove, asegura Mashov√©ts.
Otros asaltos repelidos Aunque las tropas rusas han logrado limitados progresos cerca de Ch√°siv Yar y de Toretsk, en otros lugares los asaltos rusos han sido repelidos de forma consistente. As√≠ una columna de 13 tanques y veh√≠culos acorazados fue destruida cerca de Kurajove el pasado mi√©rcoles.
El uso de equipamiento pesado por las fuerzas rusas es cada vez menos frecuente, debido a las p√©rdidas que ha sufrido en su ofensiva en Donetsk.
Aunque las bajas de personal rusas ocasionadas por la 110¬™ Brigada han aumentado en aproximadamente un tercio desde octubre de 2023, sus p√©rdidas de material han ca√≠do a un cuarto del valor original.
Defensa de Bryansk A unos 1.000 kil√≥metros al noroeste de Pokrovsk, en la frontera con Rusia al norte de Kiev, efectivos del Servicio Federal de Seguridad (FSB) ruso y de las Fuerzas Armadas repelieron un intento de incursi√≥n de un grupo armado ucraniano en la regi√≥n fronteriza de Briansk, vecina a la de Kursk, seg√∫n inform√≥ el gobernador local, Alexandr Bogomaz .
El exdiputado opositor ucraniano refugiado en Rusia, Oleg Tsariov , a√±adi√≥ en Telegram que el incidente tuvo lugar en las cercan√≠as de la localidad de Zabrama sobre las 19.10 hora de Mosc√∫ (14.10 GMT), cuando las fuerzas ucranianas intentaron avanzar con apoyo de tres blindados, pero retrocedieron tras media hora de combates.
Una hora despu√©s, las fuerzas ucranianas volvieron a atacar, pero fueron igualmente repelidos. "En total, seg√∫n fuentes locales, hab√≠a unos 200 efectivos del Ej√©rcito ucraniano", se√±al√≥ Tsariov.
